qas.question: What is a mechanical barrier in insects that protects the insect?
What is an example of a mechanical barrier on leaves?
What responses protect the lungs by mechanically ejecting pathogens from the respiratory system?
What is secreted by the respiratory tract to trap microorganisms?
The flushing action of what expels pathogens from the eyes?
What kind of barrier does not protect organisms from infection?
What is an example of a chemical barrier?
What is the last line of defense against infection?
What ejects pathogens from the gastrointestinal tract?
What is not an example of a mechanical barrier?

context: Several barriers protect organisms from infection, including <b5_0>mechanical<b5_0/>, chemical, and biological barriers. <a1_0>The <a1_1><a1_2><b6_0>waxy cuticle<b6_0/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/> of many leaves, the <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2>exoskeleton<a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> of insects, the shells and membranes of externally deposited eggs, and <b9_0>skin<b9_0/> are examples of <b7_0>mechanical barriers<b7_0/> that are the first line of defense against infection. However, as organisms cannot be completely sealed from their environments, other systems act to protect body openings such as the lungs, intestines, and the genitourinary tract. In the lungs, <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><b8_0>coughing and sneezing<b8_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/> mechanically eject pathogens and other irritants from the respiratory tract. The flushing action of <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2>tears<a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/> and urine also mechanically expels pathogens, while <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2>mucus<a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/> secreted by the respiratory and gastrointestinal tract serves to trap and entangle microorganisms.
